channel.title: Android Tablet
channel.description:
Has anyone got experience with android tablets? is the asus eee a good contender? I can pick one up with the keyboard, which adds battery life, for £339. What I need to know is it worth it?
http://uk.asus.com/Eee/Eee_Pad/Eee_Pad_Transformer_TF101/
[img]http://uk.asus.com/websites/global/products/gHh4q7I8dvWJzhdV/P_500.jpg[/img]

item.title: Android Tablet
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

get ur relays and ting out bro, fuck expensive X10s

Read full topic

item.title: Android Tablet
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Haven’t purchased anything yet in regards to that side of things, I have access to Phidgets sensors and motors (I have the #2 kit), and am building an API to interact with it and external data feeds, for the home automation I would just need to write some new output classes. I don’t know if the way I have set it up is the best way but I create scripts for each check I want and have them in their own thread checking if they should be activated and interact, Time will tell when I am able to test this in a real working model.

http://www.uk-automation.co.uk/ is what I will be possibly using, but Google has lots of vendors here in the UK so I’m spoilt for choice really.

This will most likely be Installed in either my family home or family business

Read full topic

going to save my monies![/quote]
Wait for the Tegra 3 quad core generation, will be looking at some serious speed then, and for only around $300 or less.

item.title: Android Tablet

item.description:

this is me using a slider input to control a motor, and a touch sensor to control a motor and a led.

NrllK.png1280×800

edit: OK I have my hands on a asus eee transformer (borrowed from my lecturer) and I’m not too impressed, its not fast enough and doesn’t offer me enough to validate spending £400.

going to save my monies!

Read full topic

item.title: Android Tablet
item.dc:creator: @_Rick1 _Rick
item.description:
@_Rick1 wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:9, topic:420363”]Yea I’m going to wait for one running 4.0.

I’m actually getting a tablet so I can create a Intelligent House App, basically so I can control sensors and outputs to do certain actions. Such as ensure my windows are locked (touch sensor), that I have turned the heating / oven off (temperature sensor), motion sensor for intruders, with a usb camera to capture, I also want to have an RFID in use somewhere, maybe to unlock my PC or turn on some devices, or to turn off the alarm?

If you’re interested I will have finished the development of the program around april next year, I’m using the Phidgets kit #2. What sparked my interest is that my dissertation project is to create a led facade for the new arts building using sensor and external data feeds, it will actually be on show and I assume will hit the news as it is £35m new building in manchester.

The tablet would be 3G and would go with me to uni / work. I would probably have to create some form of iphone application to track location so that it knows when i am at home, the main reason for using a tablet would be screen size, plus processing power.

Plus I can watch movies on the go :p[/quote]

Interesting idea to do this with something like a tablet. Will be following

Read full topic

item.title: Android Tablet
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Yea I’m going to wait for one running 4.0.

I’m actually getting a tablet so I can create a Intelligent House App, basically so I can control sensors and outputs to do certain actions. Such as ensure my windows are locked (touch sensor), that I have turned the heating / oven off (temperature sensor), motion sensor for intruders, with a usb camera to capture, I also want to have an RFID in use somewhere, maybe to unlock my PC or turn on some devices, or to turn off the alarm?

If you’re interested I will have finished the development of the program around april next year, I’m using the Phidgets kit #2. What sparked my interest is that my dissertation project is to create a led facade for the new arts building using sensor and external data feeds, it will actually be on show and I assume will hit the news as it is £35m new building in manchester.

The tablet would be 3G and would go with me to uni / work. I would probably have to create some form of iphone application to track location so that it knows when i am at home, the main reason for using a tablet would be screen size, plus processing power.

Plus I can watch movies on the go

Read full topic

item.title: Android Tablet
item.dc:creator: @_Rick1 _Rick
item.description:
@_Rick1 wrote:

Moparisthebest:

That’s what the official story is, I guess we will soon see won’t we?

It happened! Google officially released the Android 4.0 (Icecream sandwich) source code.

Android Open Source Project

Android Open Source Project

Android unites the world! Use the open source Android operating system to power your device.

About the tablet; I’d wait for a tablet with a bit higher specifications and running Android 4.0 which is apparently going to make all the difference.
Ofcourse it still depends on what you want to use the tablet for. If you are going to use it to sit on the couch and read the latest topics on these forums a tablet is a good thing, if you want to use it as something to use when you randomly get productive and want to start doing things like writing code on it, i’d rather go for a Windows 7 tablet with good specs, just because you can run for example your favorite IDE on it.

Ofcourse I also have to mention that most android tablets can be flashed easily and you can run pretty much any Linux distribution with an ARM version on them (especially Ubuntu, which I run on my Android phone that I use for experimenting). The whole tablet thing is pretty interesting actually.

Read full topic

item.title: Android Tablet
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

They didnt release the source code for honeycomb because they didn’t want OEMs to run off with it and start doing their own stuff. Honeycomb was thrown together because of the iPad, they had nothing to compete with it for a year.

They are, however, going to release the source code for Ice cream sandwich, which brings both the phone OS and tablet OS together.

Read full topic

item.description:

Google just declared they weren’t going to release any source code for honeycomb, so I’d probably stay away from android tablets with it on there.

@Asus EEE PC, I have a slightly older one (with an Intel Atom CPU) that I run Kubuntu on and it works great.

item.title: Android Tablet
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Honeycomb itself is quite good. But it’s application ecosystem isn’t great, and with Google recently claiming they don’t like the approach where applications should have different interfaces between phones, it seems they just don’t quite get it yet.

Read full topic
